CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1 (length);Violation of Art. 13;Remainder inadmissible;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses (domestic proceedings) - claim dismissed;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in Cork . He is a medical doctor . In DATE a formal complaint was made to the police by a former female patient that she had been indecently assaulted by the applicant and that he had made video recordings . On DATE a search warrant was obtained . On DATE his home , clinic and consulting rooms were searched . Videos were found reflecting matters similar to those about which the woman had complained . Pills obtained by a prescription made out to , and using the medical card of , another patient were found although that patient knew nothing of the pills . A replica pistol and blank ammunition were found . The applicant was questioned . He admitted that he had obtained pills in that manner for DATE .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) was informed of a number of complaints against him by CARDINAL former female patients and , in DATE , the police confirmed to the ORG that they were investigating allegations of indecent assault by the applicant . In DATE the ORG received written complaints from those CARDINAL patients alleging sexual assault and blackmail . On DATE ORG ( “ the Committee ” ) of the ORG decided that there was a prima facie case for the holding of an enquiry .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG made an order ( unpublished ) restraining him from practising pending the outcome of the inquiry . On DATE ORG ordered the removal of the applicant ’s name from the register of practitioner ’s and restrained him from practising pending the inquiry and all consequent proceedings . ORG also agreed that the ORG could make public the “ sequence of events ” including the orders of DATE and CARDINAL DATE . ORG issued a press release on DATE which included the applicant ’s name , the terms of those CARDINAL ORG orders and details of how an individual could complain to the ORG about a medical practitioner . Further complaints ( CARDINAL ) were then received from other former female patients of the applicant , of which CARDINAL made formal statements to the police .

CARDINAL . The applicant left GPE for DATE to avoid the publicity but kept in contact with the police through his solicitor . On DATE he attended with his solicitor , and by prearranged appointment , at a police station to enquire as to whether there were criminal charges pending against him . He claims that he was informed that no charges were pending . However , on DATE when he voluntarily attended the same police station with his solicitor , his solicitor insisted on attending the interview , the police refused and , given the dispute , arrested the applicant ( under LAW DATE – for the proper investigation of a crime - on suspicion of sexual assault of a former patient ) during which period the applicant saw his solicitor . The period of lawful detention expired that TIME : that TIME he appeared voluntarily before a High Court judge in his habeas corpus application . That application was later determined against him .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Chief State Solicitor advised the applicant that certain summonses had issued against him . The applicant was served at his solicitor ’s office . The charges concerned the pills , replica pistol and ammunition found . On DATE these charges were , pursuant to his application , struck out for lack of evidence .

CARDINAL . On unspecified dates , certain former patients , also complainants in the criminal proceedings , initiated civil actions against the applicant alleging sexual assault . These proceedings are defended by the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant informed the ORG that the criminal proceedings had been favourably disposed of and that the pending civil actions against him ( by patients who had not complained to ORG ) would be vigorously defended : he asked for the resumption of the disciplinary inquiry . A hearing was held on DATE and the ORG rejected his request to hold the inquiry in public . The applicant ’s request for leave to apply for judicial review of that decision was rejected by ORG but was granted by ORG ( DATE ) . ORG ( DATE ) and then ORG ( DATE ) rejected the substantive judicial review application and appeal , respectively . When it became subsequently clear that sexual assault charges would be pursued against him , the ORG proceedings were stayed .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant was served with a routine summons under LAW DATE ( in order to allow them to dispose of the blank ammunition and the replica pistol ) . That summons lapsed as it was returnable for a bank holiday .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested on foot of a warrant ( issued on DATE ) in respect of an alleged sexual assault of a former patient on a date between DATE and CARDINAL DATE . A list of all charges concerning CARDINAL complainants was read to him later in the police station : he was thereby formally charged with CARDINAL offences of a sexual nature . He was brought before ORG TIME to considerable media attention . Bail was opposed but granted on condition that he report to a police station every DATE TIME . His passport was impounded .

CARDINAL . On DATE he unsuccessfully applied for a copy of the statement grounding the application for his arrest warrant . On DATE he was given leave to apply for judicial review for an order prohibiting his prosecution on CARDINAL grounds , including “ gross and inexcusable delay ” . A stay on prosecution was granted pending the determination of the judicial review proceedings .

CARDINAL . In DATE and DATE the respondents submitted a statement of opposition and CARDINAL affidavits . On DATE an order for discovery was made against the respondents . In DATE , DATE and DATE the proceedings were adjourned on the application of the respondents . In DATE the respondents filed their first affidavit of discovery and in DATE the applicant requested further discovery . The proceedings were adjourned CARDINAL times DATE at the respondents’ request . On DATE the respondents requested the hearing of the substantive matter ; on DATE they filed a further affidavit of discovery ; on DATE the applicant issued a motion requesting further and better discovery ; and on DATE the respondents requested that a date be fixed for the substantive hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the applicant to file an affidavit listing those documents over which he disputed the respondents’ assertion of privilege . The applicant filed an affidavit on DATE but it was later found not to have complied with the order of CARDINAL DATE . In response , the respondents filed affidavits on DATE . On DATE the High Court heard the applicant ’s motion for further discovery , ordered the respondents to make further discovery by DATE and the matter was adjourned to DATE . On DATE the applicant filed an affidavit complaining , inter alia , about delay in the case . On DATE , and further to the respondents’ submission that another affidavit and discovery would be soon ready , the matter was adjourned to CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was informed that a further adjournment would be applied for by the respondents . On DATE the adjournment was accorded by ORG ( until DATE ) . The applicant filed an affidavit on that date again complaining about delay . The respondents filed further affidavits in DATE and DATE as did the applicant on DATE . On DATE a further adjournment was accorded , with the applicant ’s consent on the basis that the respondents furnish him with all non - contested documents by DATE . On DATE ORG ordered him to clarify within DATE the documents in respect of which he contested the privilege claimed by the respondents . On DATE the applicant filed a further affidavit .

CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing of the application for further and better discovery resumed . At this hearing the applicant indicated that he disputed privilege in relation to the ORG statements and the medical reports . The court ordered the respondents to make the ORG statements available to the applicant ( with addresses blocked out ) . It made no order as regards the respondents’ medical reports and indicated that it would provide the first available date for the hearing of the substantive judicial review matter .

CARDINAL . In DATE the substantive judicial review hearing was fixed for DATE . However , on DATE , the respondents filed another CARDINAL affidavits . As a result , the substantive hearing had to be adjourned . Both parties were in agreement that the case should not be re - listed until ORG had given judgment in a case which was relevant to one ( not delay ) of the grounds of review ( “ the related case ” ) .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , the procedural disputes continued . The applicant disputed the claimed privilege during a hearing from CARDINAL to CARDINAL DATE . During a hearing on DATE , DATE and DATE the applicant sought further inspection of the respondents’ documents . On DATE ORG refused this application . It noted that , while the respondents had been “ grossly in delay ” in filing the affidavits in DATE , the information contained therein had not added anything material to the case . It also noted that the applicant had not complied with ORG order of CARDINAL DATE to specify which of the documents , in which the respondents were claiming privilege , were being disputed .
CARDINAL . ORG gave judgment in the related case in DATE . The applicant ’s substantive hearing was set down for DATE . It ended on DATE and judgment was reserved .

CARDINAL . On DATE the High Court delivered its judgment refusing the relief ( prohibition of prosecution ) sought by the applicant . It found that both parties were at fault for the delay caused by the discovery process : the applicant for not being more focused as to the documents he required ( and in particular not complying with the order of CARDINAL DATE ) ; the respondents for being slow to furnish discovery . It also stated that the respondents had been entirely to blame for the adjournment of the proceedings on DATE . However , it considered that this default had not caused any significant delay because the proceedings had to be adjourned anyway to await the judgment in the related case . Accordingly , by judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG removed the stay on prosecution and ordered the applicant to pay the ORG ’s costs .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant appealed ( against the refusal of the prohibition order and the order for costs ) . In DATE ORG heard the appeal . On DATE it rejected the appeal concerning the refusal of the prohibition order . It considered that some of the delay in the judicial review proceedings was the fault of the applicant ( for not complying with the order of CARDINAL DATE ) ; some was necessary ( in order to await the judgment in the related case ) ; some was caused by ORG ( “ ORG ” ) ( in particular the adjournments they sought during the protracted discovery process ) ; and some was caused by ORG ( in failing to deliver judgment for DATE ) . It held that it could only take into account the delay for which the ORG was responsible .
CARDINAL . As to the “ considerable delay ” of ORG in delivering judgment , it said :

“ ... it is a complete misunderstanding of the decision of ORG in PERSON v. GPE [ no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALX ( extracts ) ] to treat it as authority for the proposition that , in a case such as the present , the right of the public , as represented by the ORG , to the trial of serious offences can be defeated by a delay for which the prosecuting authorities bore no responsibility . The decision of the majority of the [ C]ourt in PERSON ... does not have the effect of entitling a party in the domestic courts to relief which would otherwise not be available to him . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG affirmed the costs order of ORG and required the applicant to pay the respondents’ costs .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant was informed by the police that , in light of ORG judgment , the prosecution would proceed before ORG on DATE . On DATE , the prosecutor withdrew charges concerning CARDINAL complainants but maintained the charges of sexual assault concerning CARDINAL complainants . The prosecution sought and was granted an adjournment ( until DATE ) to allow it to prepare a Book of Evidence after which it was envisaged that the charges would be transferred for trial on indictment . On DATE ORG lifted his bail conditions . It ordered the transfer of the charges to ORG for trial on indictment . ORG refused to conduct a preliminary examination of the charges under Part II of LAW DATE ( which provision had been repealed by Part III of LAW DATE in DATE ) . On DATE the High Court granted leave to seek judicial review of this refusal by ORG .

A medical report dated DATE concluded that the applicant ’s advanced age and the ongoing prosecution “ have affected his physical and mental condition to such an extent that at this point in time his capacity to defend himself is impaired ” . ORG disciplinary proceedings and the civil assault actions have been adjourned pending the criminal proceedings .
